author: Robyn Ironside National Aviation Writer
title: Qantas and Virgin Australia compete fiercely for corporate travel market
text:
THIS is the reason why Qantas and Virgin Australia compete so fiercely for the corporate travel market.
Figures from the Global Business Travel Association show in 2014, Australian companies and individuals spent $20.5 billion on business travel — or $56 million a day.
The figure represented a 1.3 per cent increase on the previous year, and made Australia the 13th biggest spender in the world on business travel.
The US and China led the pack followed by Japan, Germany, the UK, France, South Korea and Brazil.
Italy, Indian, Canada and Russia also spent more on business travel than Australia. Gourmet ... Qantas international menus for First and Business class. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied
Globally, business travel spending is tipped to reach $1.25 trillion in 2015 up from $1.18 trillion last year.
Growth is then expected to continue at an average six per cent a year as a result of a massive increase in business travel out of China.
American Express Global Business Travel Vice-President David Reimer said predictions that technology such as Skype and email would be the death of business travel, had been well off the mark.
“In fact it’s quite the opposite. People use those technologies as a complimentary service,” said Mr Reimer.
“Particularly within the Asia Pacific, there’s nothing like that human element, that human contact, the ability to shake hands on a deal.
“Building up a business partnership is all about personalisation. I don’t think that’s going to be replaced anytime soon.” Improving the experience ... Virgin Australia boss John Borghetti believes the airline’s enhanced Super Diamond “business first” suite will only knock his opposition “out of the park’’. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied
He said Australian business people were among the biggest travellers in the world, as a result of the country’s “challenging” geography.
“Australians have to travel to make themselves relevant; they have to go that extra distance,” Mr Reimer said.
“We’re certainly seeing growth in business travel to the US which is no surprise given the improving economy. Australians want to be amongst that.”
Fierce competition among airlines for the corporate dollar has made life a bit easier for business travellers with lounges, lie-flat beds, restaurant quality meals and express processing now par for the course.
Although business fares have almost returned to what they were before Virgin Australia took the fight up to Qantas in late 2011, Mr Reimer said most companies were happy to invest in the pointy end of the plane for key people. Luxury ... Virgin Australia’s new business class suites to be installed on A330 and 777 fleets. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied
“You’re certainly seeing companies recognise that need for people to turn up fresh and hit the ground running, which means they view business travel as an investment rather than an expense,” he said.
“Companies on the whole are very considerate of the experience their people have, and half an hour saved queuing up at an airport is valuable time.”
Virgin Australia has set itself a goal of carrying 30 per cent of the Australian corporate market by 2017, six years after the airline began its transformation from budget to premium carrier.
But Qantas is not giving up any market share without a fight, having beaten its rival to new state of the art business suites on its A330 fleet earlier this year.
Business passengers will finally get to experience Virgin Australia’s new suites, from mid-August.
